1.text: And the Pharisees and some of the scribes, arriving from Jerusalem, gathered together before him.

2.text: And when they had seen certain ones from his disciples eating bread with common hands, that is, with unwashed hands, they disparaged them.

3.text: For the Pharisees, and all the Jews, do not eat without repeatedly washing their hands, holding to the tradition of the elders.

4.text: And when returning from the market, unless they wash, they do not eat. And there are many other things which have been handed down to them to observe: the washings of cups, and pitchers, and bronze containers, and beds.

5.text: And so the Pharisees and the scribes questioned him: “Why do your disciples not walk according to the tradition of the elders, but they eat bread with common hands?”

6.text: But in response, he said to them: “So well did Isaiah prophesy about you hypocrites, just as it has been written: ‘This people honors me with their lips, but their heart is far from me.

7.text: And in vain do they worship me, teaching the doctrines and precepts of men.’

8.text: For abandoning the commandment of God, you hold to the tradition of men, to the washing of pitchers and cups. And you do many other things similar to these.”

9.text: And he said to them: “You effectively nullify the precept of God, so that you may observe your own tradition.

10.text: For Moses said: ‘Honor your father and your mother,’ and, ‘Whoever will have cursed father or mother, let him die a death.’

11.text: But you say, ‘If a man will have said to his father or mother: Korban, (which is a gift) whatever is from me will be to your benefit,’

12.text: then you do not release him to do anything for his father or mother,

13.text: rescinding the word of God through your tradition, which you have handed down. And you do many other similar things in this way.”

14.text: And again, calling the crowd to him, he said to them: “Listen to me, all of you, and understand.

15.text: There is nothing from outside a man which, by entering into him, is able to defile him. But the things which procede from a man, these are what pollute a man.

16.text: Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.”

17.text: And when he had entered into the house, away from the crowd, his disciples questioned him about the parable.

18.text: And he said to them: “So, are you also without prudence? Do you not understand that everything entering to a man from outside is not able to pollute him?

19.text: For it does not enter into his heart, but into the gut, and it exits into the sewer, purging all foods.”

20.text: “But,” he said “the things which go out from a man, these pollute a man.

21.text: For from within, from the heart of men, proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders,

22.text: thefts, avarice, wickedness, deceitfulness, homosexuality, an evil eye, blasphemy, self-exaltation, foolishness.

23.text: All these evils procede from within and pollute a man.”

24.text: And rising up, he went from there to the area of Tyre and Sidon. And entering into a house, he intended no one to know about it, but he was not able to remain hidden.

25.text: For a woman whose daughter had an unclean spirit, as soon as she heard about him, entered and fell prostrate at his feet.

26.text: For the woman was a Gentile, by birth a Syro-Phoenician. And she petitioned him, so that he would cast the demon from her daughter.

27.text: And he said to her: “First allow the sons to have their fill. For it is not good to take away the bread of the sons and throw it to the dogs.”

28.text: But she responded by saying to him: “Certainly, Lord. Yet the young dogs also eat, under the table, from the crumbs of the children.”

29.text: And he said to her, “Because of this saying, go; the demon has gone out of your daughter.”

30.text: And when she had gone to her house, she found the girl lying on the bed; and the demon had gone away.

31.text: And again, departing from the borders of Tyre, he went by way of Sidon to the sea of Galilee, through the midst of the area of the Ten Cities.

32.text: And they brought someone who was deaf and mute to him. And they begged him, so that he would lay his hand upon him.

33.text: And taking him away from the crowd, he put his fingers into his ears; and spitting, he touched his tongue.

34.text: And gazing up to heaven, he groaned and said to him: “Ephphatha,” which is, “Be opened.”

35.text: And immediately his ears were opened, and the impediment of his tongue was released, and he spoke correctly.

36.text: And he instructed them not to tell anyone. But as much as he instructed them, so much more did they preach about it.

37.text: And so much more did they wonder, saying: “He has done all things well. He has caused both the deaf to hear and the mute to speak.”
